Vela PIRs can make use of the cloud to build applications this is going to be a bit of a quick tour around AWS just to
introduce Amazon Web Services to you if you're completely new to the topic and then we'll also spend a little bit of
time talking about places you can go and resources that you can use to learn more about how you can build apps using the
AWS cloud we'll have this session every morning this week at 10:00 and then I'll close up today by talking about what we
have on the content agenda for the rest of the day we have 21 sessions here at Web Summit in Lisbon over the course of
the next three days covering all kinds of different aspects of using the cloud to build applications so hopefully
there'll be something for everybody here at the show and hopefully you'll return if you're with us on Twitch or in the theater here and watch and listen to
avail the presenters over the course of the next three days okay oh by the way I mean amassing him yeah I lead a
developer evangelism at AWS and have lots of my team here from around the world actually to talk to you over the
course of the the program here at Web Summit this week okay so what's
different about AWS in the cloud I know that the audience here is on the younger end of the scale in the main part
substantially younger than me a lot of cases but who was using technology to
create applications or run services say 10 to 12 years ago ok a minority of
people so if everybody that didn't put their hand up let me tell you that in the old days we
used to have to wait for things okay Wendy one of the service or a server we would open a ticket with a IT team the
IT team would go away and buy stuff okay and then weeks or months later we would get the technology that we needed to run
our app or deploy our software can you imagine that sounds stupid right but that's actually what old people like me
used to do for years and years and years and today we don't do that anymore
okay so let's ask a different question if you were starting today to build a new app or build a brand new business
that needed technology how many people would actually buy infrastructure of any type and own and operate infrastructure
of any type in order to do that in order to do things like run email provide collaboration services post websites run
the backend for a mobile app analyze data or any other things that are really important in building a business who
would buy server infrastructure in order to do that if they were starting today if you at the front
I'll just reassure you that nobody behind you is putting you at their hand up either all right so you're not alone in keeping your hands down this is just
not how we do technology anymore the way we do technology now is by using
services and in the main part we provision those services using api's we might have a console console or a
website on the front of it but in the main part the services at the back end are getting built out using an API layer
that provisions all the resources forwards in a way which just a few years ago we'd have thought was kind of like
magic really in terms of the capabilities that are our fingertips this is completely different to how
things used to be and that's really the shift that's happened over the course of the last twelve to ten years
AWS was launched back in 2006 and we were the first cloud provider to offer services under this model and just in
that short period of 12 years everything's changed right we use services today in a completely different way to how we used to use them before
and what this means for developers and for product builders and for business people is you can now focus on the
things that are unique about your particular idea or you Niq about your particular business you
don't have to get involved in these low level infrastructure activities these low level technology activities that
have been done by businesses since technology was invented you can hand all that stuff over to a platform and you
can focus on the things that are really unique about your particular problem space unique about the business that
you're trying to build and that is again really really different to how things used to be okay so what do we actually
have I'll talk about services quite a few times there and I've talked about provisioning services using an API but
what do we actually have in terms of services that developers can make use of well the simple answer to that question
is we have a lot of stuff we have over 125 different services that you can make
use of today so many in fact that this slide is kind of useless because even if you like me right up on stage you can't
read any of this stuff so let's just take a quick tour about some of the most important parts of the platform for
developers and give you a flavor of what we have and how you can put some of these services to work okay
infrastructure and core services infrastructure in AWS is organized into
regions we have 18 of these geographic regions around the world that customers can use several in the US here in Europe
we have Dublin London Paris and Frankfurt with another one coming in Stockholm in a few months time okay so
these infrastructure regions are the places in the world where you create the resources that you want to use to build or when your applications why might I
choose a specific region over another region there's basically three reasons the first is latency it pays for me to
put my application close to where my users are if anyone's ever played a first-person shooter like counter-strike
or destiny you will know what the effect of lag is what the effect of latency is
on your effectiveness in playing that game you get hammered by the people that have got lower latency than you and that
experience improvement carries over into online applications as well there's lots
of research out there that shows that there's a direct correlation between good application performance and people
using your applications or services to a greater degree not only in gaming but also in web
like amazon.com for example we've observed that the low lower we drive latency the more money people will spend
on the website they have a higher propensity to buy with a really snappy user experience so put your application
close to where your customers are that's the first thing second thing is compliance so you might have a
requirement to keep your data in a certain geography for legislative or regulatory reasons okay in Australia for
example if you're serving financial services customers you want to have your data in Australia and keep your data in
Australia you can use our Sydney region to do that we never move data out of a region autonomously you as a customer
can copy it from region to region but we never move data out of a region without your directive to do so ok so you can
select your region based on a particular location that you need to be in with your app and then thirdly cost there's a
differential pricing model here not all regions cost the same if you want to use our region in Sao Paulo Brazil you'll
find that it's slightly more expensive than a region in Dublin Ireland for example so if you really genuinely don't
care where your application or workload runs you can run it in a location which is cost optimal or you can blend those
things together I want to have a lowest cost region that's within 50 milliseconds of where my users are for
example and take a couple of different factors into account okay so that's regions and infrastructure we also have
over a hundred and ten points of presence around the world for further
improving the experience for your customers using apps built on the platform this supports services like
route 53 which is our DNS resolver and also services like our API gateway and
services like caching in our content distribution network as well so you can push some services out right to one of
those edge locations and benefit from really accelerated performance by doing that so that's all in this
infrastructure category down here then we have core services and these were
some of the original services that AWS launched back in 2006 services for
running virtual machines in the cloud it's something called Amazon ec2 or the elastic compute cloud makes it really
easy to spin up a machine actually over 15 different types of virtual hardware platform that you can
use there with all kinds of special resources like field programmable gate arrays or FPGA s for silicon accelerated
algorithm performance or high-performance FPU is floating-point units for running deep learning Newell
network model training applications so you can use special-purpose computer resources within this ec2 service
there's also lots of services for things like networking for load balancing for laying out networks in a way which
matches your security compliance or performance requirements there are storage services a service called Amazon
s3 this is for object storage it's also a very high-performance highly durable highly scalable web server that you can
use to host static websites or to deliver content to users and then we have database services in the form of
relational database service as a service called RDS supports many different types of relational database engine you can
spin up your DB instance in the cloud you can establish replication across what we call availability zones within a
region and this will give you high performance high durability an excellent failover characteristics for your
critical data stores inside a relational data model or you can create DynamoDB
tables this is our non-relational no sequel database service that allows you to establish a simpler data model but
with very very high local low latency performance for critical apps used really extensively and things like
mobile gaming where scalability and performance is a really key criteria for application developers of course so we
have all kinds of services for data storage there these are our core
services that you provision within these infrastructure regions around the world should say a little bit more about
availability zones actually I mentioned it there when I was talking about databases but within each of our regions
we have multiple availability zones and those availability zones or AZ's as we
call them are independent failure domains so you can deploy your application across multiple failure
domains multiple data centers directly from the AWS console or from one of our SDKs or API so it puts
I'd say that it puts infrastructure into the hands of individual developers that
for a long time was the preserve of the ultra well capitalized financial services institution or the government
departments of this world that have very deep pockets and lots of resources now as an individual developer you can build
applications that are very durable by using that availability zone construct striping your application in data across
multiple data centers in the same region and giving you the capability to tolerate failures so if a data center
fails your application can continue to run okay so that's what the availability zone construct is for next thing to talk
about is security in compliance and this is a really substantial investment area for Amazon Web Services we spend a lot
of money to ensure that our services are operated in a way which complies with
important information security and governance standards that are of course absolutely critical to customers we also
spend a lot of money on service innovation in this area to create new services that allow customers to further
enhance their security posture in the cloud and this is a counterintuitive
characteristic of AWS that I I really love it the fact that a few years ago
customers would say we're nervous about using the cloud is it secure can we meet
the compliance standards that we need to meet if we use the cloud and if you talk to substantial users of AWS today in
financial services in government in retail they're saying exactly the opposite they're saying is it safe for
us to stay in our own data centers do we have the skills infrastructure investment and capabilities that we need
to operate our own technology in a way which meets the high standard set by AWS
ok so the situation is completely flipped ok and that is because for us
information security is a core platform characteristic when we improve the
platform for one customer in finance or one customer in public sector every other customer that chooses to use AWS
benefits from that improvement so if you're a two-person startup you've got access to cryptography auditing
identity based access management that is exactly the same as the world's largest
investment banks there is literally no difference between the capabilities that you have so again it's democratizing
access to really high quality technology and it's offloading heavy lifting from developers in an area of risk to a
provider that can do that as a natural component of the services that they provide ok we have transparency on our
auditing and compliance capabilities and
if you visit aws.amazon.com slash compliance you can download compliance
reports for things like PCI DSS for HIPAA which is a Health Information protection standard that is applicable
in the US for ISO 27001 for ISO 27:18
which is the cloud and privacy standard you can access information about gdpr compliance on AWS as well so everything
is there transparently available for customers to use and take advantage of
moving up the stack a little bit out of these foundational components which are key to everything that we do we also
have higher level services that developers can directly use to build applications we have a full suite of
services for Internet of Things or connected device applications ranging from device side SDKs that you can put
onto your wearables microcontroller based systems I want to other connected devices that you might be building
including a microcontroller operating system that we support and maintain
called three artists which includes integration into AWS IOT as well as the
backend components for IOT such as messaging gateways Identity and Access Management the ability to run code in
response to events which might originate on connected devices as well as data synchronization and device state
management so there's a full suite of services for IOT apps and similarly in the machine learning in AI space we have
a complete full portfolio of services for machine learning developers as well
as a portfolio of AI services for developers that want to incorporate features like natural language
understanding or image processing or speech generation directly into their applications as well
and we're going to have lots of content in the theater this week focusing on AI and machine learning it's an incredibly hot topic area for developers and if you
want to learn more about many of the services that you can see here in this in this area come and see us in the
course of the program and check out some of our a AI and machine learning sessions and then we have analytics and
data engineering services these are for things like dealing with streaming data
clickstream data in applications for example or streaming telemetry data that might come off connected device
applications you can process that data analyze it and take action based on that analysis natively in the cloud these are
managed services that offload the heavy lifting associated with doing things like running kafka clusters or operating
Hadoop or SPARC infrastructure that you might want to run in order to build these kinds of high volume high
performance very reliable data engineering applications we have a complete suite of services for that
stuff app services this is for building loosely coupled applications with really
good durability and failure tolerance characteristics it's for embedding search or workflow into apps that you
might be building or for sending transactional email to customers using our service SES so you can plug these
components directly into your apps using our SDKs and benefit from very reliable
durable reusable service components that again remove the need for you to build things that have been built before then
we have tools for managing the systems development lifecycle in the form of DevOps tools we have a complete suite of
services for mobile applications as well and also for browser-based apps which we'll cover in more detail over the
course of the content program here this week but you can incorporate an AWS SDK directly into an Android or iOS app we
can manage identity for you we can manage social sign-on we can manage push notifications we can manage in app
analytics for you we can do all of that using a simple-to-use suite of cloud services that you can integrate natively
into your iOS or Android development pipelines so there's a huge amount of
stuff there for developers of all types and we'll talk about many of these topics in a lot
more detail over the course of the week this is just a 25,000 foot preview of some of the stuff that we have coming up now there's a lot of

into substantially less than 365 days so the average launch for it is you know
